company.name: Life is good, Inc.
company.business_description: Life is good, Inc. designs and distributes retail apparel and accessories and operates a retail website at www.lifeisgood.com.

case_info.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

complaint.factual_background: Life is Good, Inc. and its subsidiary Life is Good Retail, Inc. operated a retail website that collected sensitive consumer information including names, addresses, credit card numbers, expiration dates, and security codes. Despite publicly claiming to keep all consumer information in a 'secure file,' respondents stored data in clear readable text, retained credit card security codes without business need, and failed to assess or defend against common vulnerabilities such as SQL injection attacks. Between June and August 2006, a hacker exploited these failures via SQL injection attacks, exporting thousands of customers' credit card details. Respondents only became aware of the breach after being notified by their own customers.

representations_made.description: Claimed to maintain customer privacy by keeping all collected information — including name, address, credit card, and phone numbers — in a secure file
representations_made.quoted_text: We are committed to maintaining our customers’ privacy. We collect and store information you share with us – name, address, credit card and phone numbers – along with information about products and services you request. All information is kept in a secure file and is used to tailor our communications with you.

counts.title: Data Security Misrepresentation
counts.representation: Through their website privacy policy, respondents represented, expressly or by implication, that they implemented reasonable and appropriate measures to protect consumer information against unauthorized access.
counts.fact: Respondents did not implement reasonable and appropriate measures to protect consumer information against unauthorized access. Specifically, they stored data in clear text, retained credit card security codes unnecessarily, failed to assess vulnerabilities to common attacks such as SQL injection, did not implement readily available defenses, did not monitor network connections, and failed to detect unauthorized access — failures that enabled a hacker to export thousands of customers' credit card records.
counts.conclusion: Therefore, the representation set forth in Paragraph 7 was, and is, false or misleading, constituting deceptive acts or practices in or affecting commerce in violation of Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act.

definitions.Personally identifiable information / pe: individually identifiable information from or about an individual consumer including, but not limited to: (a) a first and last name; (b) a home or other physical address, including street name and name of city or town; (c) an email address or other online contact information, such as an instant messaging user identifier or a screen name that reveals an individual's email address; (d) a telephone number; (e) a Social Security number; (f) credit or debit card information, including card number, expiration date, and security code; (g) a persistent identifier, such as a customer number held in a "cookie" or processor serial number, that is combined with other available data that identifies an individual consumer; or (h) any information that is combined with any of (a) through (g) above.
definitions.Respondents: Life is good, Inc., Life is good Retail, Inc., and their successors and assigns, officers, agents, representatives, subsidiaries, affiliates, and employees.
definitions.Commerce: as defined in Section 4 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 44.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Privacy and Security
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent in any manner, expressly or by implication, the extent to which they maintain and protect the privacy, confidentiality, or integrity of personal information collected from consumers.

requirements.description: Must not misrepresent the extent to which respondents maintain and protect the privacy, confidentiality, or integrity of any personal information collected from or about consumers
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS ORDERED that respondents, directly or through any corporation, subsidiary, division, or other device, in connection with the collection of personally identifiable information from or about consumers, in or affecting commerce, shall not misrepresent in any manner, 2 expressly or by implication, the extent to which respondents maintain and protect the privacy, confidentiality, or integrity of any personal information collected from or about consumers.

provisions.title: Comprehensive Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondents must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program with specific administrative, technical, and physical safeguards, fully documented in writing, no later than the date of service of the order.

requirements.description: Establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written information security program reasonably designed to protect the security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondents, directly or through any corporation, subsidiary, division, or other device, in connection with the advertising, marketing, promotion, offering for sale, or sale of any product or service, in or affecting commerce, shall, no later than the date of service of this order, establish and implement, and thereafter maintain, a comprehensive information security program that is reasonably designed to protect the security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information collected from or about consumers. Such program, the content and implementation of which must be fully documented in writing, shall contain administrative, technical, and physical safeguards appropriate to respondents’ size and complexity, the nature and scope of respondents’ activities, and the sensitivity of the personal information collected from or about consumers, including:

requirements.description: Designate an employee or employees to coordinate and be accountable for the information security program
requirements.quoted_text: A. the designation of an employee or employees to coordinate and be accountable for the information security program;

requirements.description: Identify material internal and external risks to the security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information and assess sufficiency of existing safeguards, covering employee training, information systems, and prevention/detection/response to attacks
requirements.quoted_text: B. the identification of material internal and external risks to the security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information that could result in the unauthorized disclosure, misuse, loss, alteration, destruction, or other compromise of such information, and assessment of the sufficiency of any safeguards in place to control these risks. At a minimum, this risk assessment should include consideration of risks in each area of relevant operation, including, but not limited to, (1) employee training and management, (2) information systems, including network and software design, information processing, storage, transmission, and disposal, and (3) prevention, detection, and response to attacks, intrusions, or other systems failure;

requirements.description: Design and implement reasonable safeguards to control identified risks, and regularly test or monitor the effectiveness of key controls, systems, and procedures
requirements.quoted_text: C. the design and implementation of reasonable safeguards to control the risks identified through risk assessment, and regular testing or monitoring of the effectiveness of the safeguards’ key controls, systems, and procedures;

requirements.description: Take reasonable steps to retain service providers capable of safeguarding personal information, require them by contract to implement and maintain appropriate safeguards, and monitor their performance
requirements.quoted_text: D. the development and use of reasonable steps to retain service providers capable of appropriately safeguarding personal information they receive from respondents, requiring service providers by contract to implement and maintain appropriate safeguards, and monitoring their safeguarding of personal information; and

requirements.description: Evaluate and adjust the information security program in light of testing results, material changes to operations or business arrangements, or other circumstances that may materially impact program effectiveness
requirements.quoted_text: E. the evaluation and adjustment of respondents’ information security program in light of the results of the testing and monitoring required by subpart C, any material changes to respondents’ operations or business arrangements, or any other circumstances that respondents know or have reason to know may have a material impact on the effectiveness of their information security program.

provisions.title: Biennial Third-Party Security Assessments
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain initial and biennial third-party security assessments from a qualified independent professional, covering specific criteria, with the initial assessment provided to the FTC within 10 days of completion.

requirements.description: Obtain an initial third-party assessment covering the first 180 days after service of the order, and biennial assessments every two years thereafter for 20 years
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that, in connection with their compliance with Part II of this order, respondents shall obtain initial and biennial assessments and reports (“Assessments”) from a qualified, objective, independent third-party professional, who uses procedures and standards generally accepted in the profession. The reporting period for the Assessments shall cover: (1) the first one hundred and eighty (180) days after service of the order for the initial Assessment; and (2) each two (2) year period thereafter for twenty (20) years after service of the order for the biennial Assessments. Each Assessment shall:
requirements.deadline: initial: 180 days after service; biennial: every 2 years for 20 years

requirements.description: Each assessment must set forth specific safeguards implemented, explain their appropriateness, explain how they meet Part II requirements, and certify the security program is operating with sufficient effectiveness
requirements.quoted_text: A. set forth the specific administrative, technical, and physical safeguards that respondents have implemented and maintained during the reporting period; B. explain how such safeguards are appropriate to respondents’ size and complexity, the nature and scope of respondents’ activities, and the sensitivity of the personal information collected from or about consumers; C. explain how the safeguards that have been implemented meet or exceed the protections required by Part II of this order; and D. certify that respondents’ security program is operating with sufficient effectiveness to provide reasonable assurance that the security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information is protected and has so operated throughout the reporting period.

requirements.description: Each assessment must be prepared and completed within 60 days after the end of the reporting period by a CISSP, CISA, GIAC-certified professional, or similarly qualified person approved by the FTC
requirements.quoted_text: Each Assessment shall be prepared and completed within sixty (60) days after the end of the reporting period to which the Assessment applies by: a person qualified as a Certified Information System Security Professional (CISSP) or as a Certified Information Systems Auditor (CISA); a person holding Global Information Assurance Certification (GIAC) from the SysAdmin, Audit, Network, Security (SANS) Institute; or a similarly qualified person or organization approved by the Associate Director for Enforcement, Bureau of Consumer Protection, Federal Trade Commission, Washington, D.C. 20580.
requirements.deadline: within 60 days after end of reporting period

requirements.description: Provide the initial assessment to the FTC Associate Director for Enforcement within 10 days after it has been prepared; retain all subsequent biennial assessments until order termination and provide them to the Associate Director within 10 days of request
requirements.quoted_text: Respondents shall provide the initial Assessment to the Associate Director for Enforcement, Bureau of Consumer Protection, Federal Trade Commission, Washington, D.C. 20580, within 4 ten (10) days after the Assessment has been prepared. All subsequent biennial Assessments shall be retained by respondents until the order is terminated and provided to the Associate Director of Enforcement within ten (10) days of request.
requirements.deadline: 10 days after preparation (initial); 10 days of request (biennial)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must maintain and make available to the FTC compliance-related documents for specified periods, and provide them within 10 days of request.

requirements.description: Maintain for 5 years any documents that contradict, qualify, or call into question respondents' compliance with this order
requirements.quoted_text: A. for a period of five (5) years, any documents, whether prepared by or on behalf of either respondent, that contradict, qualify, or call into question respondents’ compliance with this order; and

requirements.description: Maintain for 3 years after preparation of each Assessment all materials relied upon to prepare it, including plans, reports, studies, audits, policies, training materials, and assessments relating to compliance with Part II
requirements.quoted_text: B. for a period of three (3) years after the date of preparation of each Assessment required under Part III of this order, all materials relied upon to prepare the Assessment, whether prepared by or on behalf of either respondent, including but not limited to all plans, reports, studies, reviews, audits, audit trails, policies, training materials, and assessments, and any other materials relating to respondents’ compliance with Part II of this order, for the compliance period covered by such Assessment.
requirements.deadline: 3 years after preparation of each Assessment

requirements.description: Provide such documents to the Associate Director of Enforcement within 10 days of request
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent shall provide such documents to the Associate Director of Enforcement within ten (10) days of request.

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Delivery
provisions.summary: Respondents must deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, employees, agents, and representatives with relevant responsibilities, within specified timeframes.

requirements.description: Deliver a copy of the order to all current principals, officers, directors, managers, employees, agents, and representatives with responsibilities relating to the subject matter of this order within 30 days after service of the order
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondents shall deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, and managers, and to all current and future employees, agents, and representatives having responsibilities relating to the subject matter of this order. Respondents shall deliver this order to such current personnel within thirty (30) days after service of this order, and to such future personnel within thirty (30) days after the person

requirements.description: Deliver a copy of the order to all future such personnel within 30 days after they assume their position or responsibilities
requirements.quoted_text: after service of this order, and to such future personnel within thirty (30) days after the person assumes such position or responsibilities.

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondents must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations, including dissolution, merger, sale, subsidiary creation, bankruptcy, or name/address change.

requirements.description: Notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change affecting compliance obligations, including dissolution, assignment, sale, merger, creation or dissolution of subsidiaries, bankruptcy filings, or name/address changes; if fewer than 30 days' notice is possible, notify as soon as practicable
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondents and their successors and assigns shall notify the Commission at least thirty (30) days prior to any change in the corporation(s) that may affect compliance obligations arising under this order, including, but not limited to: a dissolution, assignment, sale, merger, or other action that would result in the emergence of a successor corporation; the creation or dissolution of a subsidiary, parent, or affiliate that engages in any acts or practices subject to this order; the proposed filing of a bankruptcy petition; or a change in the corporate name or address. Provided, however, that, with respect to any proposed change in the corporation(s) about which respondents learn fewer than thirty (30) days prior to the date such 5 action is to take place, respondents shall notify the Commission as soon as is practicable after obtaining such knowledge. All notices required by this Part shall be sent by certified mail to the Associate Director, Division of Enforcement, Bureau of Consumer Protection, Federal Trade Commission, Washington, D.C. 20580.
requirements.deadline: at least 30 days prior to change (or as soon as practicable)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondents must file a written compliance report with the FTC within 180 days after service of the order, and at such other times as the Commission may require.

requirements.description: File a written report with the Commission within 180 days after service of the order, and at such other times as the Commission may require, setting forth in detail the manner and form in which respondents have complied with this order
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondents and their successors and assigns shall, within one hundred and eighty (180) days after service of this order, and at such other times as the Commission may require, file with the Commission a report, in writing, setting forth in detail the manner and form in which they have complied with this order.

provisions.title: Order Duration
provisions.summary: The order terminates on April 16, 2028, or 20 years from the most recent date the FTC files a federal court complaint alleging a violation, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.

requirements.description: Order terminates on April 16, 2028, or 20 years from the most recent date the U.S. or the Commission files a federal court complaint alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later, with specified exceptions for parts with shorter terms, non-defendant respondents, and post-termination complaints
requirements.quoted_text: This order will terminate on April 16, 2028, or twenty (20) years from the most recent date that the United States or the Commission files a complaint (with or without an accompanying consent decree) in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later; provided, however, that the filing of such a complaint will not affect the duration of: A. any Part in this order that terminates in fewer than twenty (20) years; B. this order’s application to any respondent that is not named as a defendant in such complaint; and C. this order if such complaint is filed after the order has terminated pursuant to this Part. Provided, further, that if such complaint is dismissed or a federal court rules that respondent(s) did not violate any provision of the order, and the dismissal or ruling is either not appealed or upheld on appeal, then the order as to such respondent(s) will terminate according to this Part as though the complaint had never been filed, except that the order will not terminate between the date such complaint is filed and the later of the deadline for appealing such dismissal or ruling and the date such dismissal or ruling is upheld on appeal.
requirements.deadline: April 16, 2028 or 20 years from most recent enforcement complaint

duration.termination_text: This order will terminate on April 16, 2028, or twenty (20) years from the most recent date that the United States or the Commission files a complaint (with or without an accompanying consent decree) in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later; provided, however, that the filing of such a complaint will not affect the duration of: A. any Part in this order that terminates in fewer than twenty (20) years; B. this order's application to any respondent that is not named as a defendant in such complaint; and C. this order if such complaint is filed after the order has terminated pursuant to this Part.
